justification: “Variability in experimental design generally falls into one of three categories: statistically dependent sequential choices (SDSC, e.g. Balloon Analogue Risk Task, n-armed bandit tasks)….”
The same sentence lists “n-armed bandit tasks” as an SDSC example used to elicit risk preference.
The paper names “statistically independent ordered choices (SIOC, e.g. Holt and Laury gambles)” as a way risk preference is measured.
For SISC designs, the authors give “lottery tasks” as an example of single choices used to measure risk preference.
“…subjective measures, usually in the form of Likert scales … such as the Domain Specific Risk Taking (DOSPERT) Scale….” are cited as risk preference measures.
The article notes that “measures of an individual's risk preference can also come from frequency measures by tabulating the occasions on which an individual engages in risky behavior.”

measured_by: titration methods in intertemporal choice tasks
justification: For SDSC intertemporal choice tasks, the paper gives “titration methods when options presented depend on previous choice” as a way to estimate discounting parameters.
The authors describe SIOC designs (e.g., systematically increasing the larger-later amount each trial) as a method to measure temporal discounting.

measured_by: standard SISC intertemporal choice tasks (SS vs. LL)
justification: They state that the “most common” intertemporal choice paradigm is SISC, where people choose between a smaller-sooner and a larger-later option.

topic_or_construct: Impulsivity (as a proxy for temporal discounting)
justification: Under temporal discounting, the paper lists “surveys (e.g. Barratt Impulsiveness Scale, Barratt & Patton, 1983)” among elicitation methods.
